title: 104_s1241
content: The Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995 aims to ensure that programs suitable for family viewing are broadcasted throughout the day without the use of federal funds for indecent or nudity-inclusive content. Public broadcasting is required to provide educational, cultural, informational, and entertaining programming in the public interest. SEC. 4 amends Section 396(a) of title 47 to state that public broadcasting should provide educational, cultural, informational, and entertaining programming suitable for family viewing in the public interest. SEC. 5. SPECTRUM FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to use their spectrum for additional services while still providing free public broadcast programming. Regulations will ensure that proceeds benefit public broadcasting, commitments to public broadcasting are maintained, and fees for non-broadcasting use are at market rates. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to provide non-public broadcast programming for a fee between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m. or commercially sponsored programming, ensuring proceeds benefit public broadcasting and commitments are maintained. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Amends sections of title 47 to include calls to action, inducements to buy, sell, rent, or lease, and provision of price information. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed via satellite, common carrier, or other telecommunications technology for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting. The Commission can approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters if the proceeds benefit the national public broadcasting system. Agreements for programming should include provisions for public broadcasting to share in benefits from ancillary products. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement. They will also study the feasibility of merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. Additionally, educational rates will be addressed. SEC. 12. The General Accounting Office will study merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. SEC. 13. Public broadcast licensees may qualify for educational telecommunications service rates for providing public broadcasting.
